summary.para: The types supported for serialization.

remarks.para: Many of the WS_TYPEs have a corresponding type description structure which allows for additional information used to serialize or deserialize the type.

For example, the WS_INT32_TYPE has a structure which allows for constraints on the deserialized values. This is an optional type description (if not specified, the full 32-bit integer space is allowed).
Another example is the WS_STRUCT_TYPE, which allows for the specification of a user-defined structure with fields. The fields are described in a . This type description is required.

Type description pointers accompany WS_TYPE in the various APIs and structures that are based on serialization. This should be NULL or non-NULL based on whether or not the type description is not defined, optional or required.

Used when serializing an WS_XML_BUFFER*.
This type has no associated type description structure.
This type can be used with the following values:
This type can be used with the following values:
This type can be used with the following values. See the documentation for for which options are supported for a given field mapping value:
A nil value is represented using a NULL pointer.
This type does not support specifying a .
The interpretation of the contents of the WS_XML_BUFFER is as follows:

description.para: When used at the top level or with , the WS_XML_BUFFER should contain a single element which represents the attribute and element content. The local name and namespace of the element in the buffer is ignored; it is replaced with actual element name and namespace when the buffer is written. For example:
description.code:
// Element in WS_XML_BUFFER <PrefixInBuffer:LocalNameInBuffer xmlns:PrefixInBuffer="namespace-in-buffer" other-attributes> text-and-or-element-content </PrefixInBuffer:LocalNameInBuffer>
// Element that is written <NewPrefix:NewLocalName xmlns:NewPrefix="new-namespace" other-attributes> text-and-or-element-content </NewPrefix:NewLocalName>
description.para: To avoid problems with namespace collisions, it is a best practice to follow one of the following rules when selecting a namespace for the element in the buffer:

item.description: Use a namespace other than "" that is not otherwise used in the buffer.
Use the same namespace as the element that will be written.

description.para: When the value is deserialized, the element name and namespace will correspond to the element that was read.
When used with , the WS_XML_BUFFER should contain a single element which represents a single element in the XML content.

When used with , each of the WS_XML_BUFFERs that are serialized in the array has the same convention as with WS_ELEMENT_FIELD_MAPPING described above (each WS_XML_BUFFER represents a single element in the XML content).
When used with , each of the WS_XML_BUFFERs that are serialized in the array represents a single element in the XML content.
When used with , the WS_XML_BUFFER may contain zero or more top level elements or text. This content corresponds to the remaining XML content of the containing structure.

summary.para: Used when serializing two fields of a structure as a unit: a WCHAR* field which points to an array of WCHARs, and a ULONG field which contains the number of characters in the array. This type may only be used within a .

The fields can be anywhere in the contained structure and in any order, since their offsets within the structure are specified separately as part of the . The offset of the count field is specified in the countOffset field, and the offset of the chars field is specified in the offset field.
Embedded zeros are allowed in the array of characters.
The type description can optionally be specified for this type in order to constrain the allowed values.
This type cannot be used with any values.
This type may only be used within a .
This type can be used with the following values:
This type can be used with the following values. See the documentation for for which options are supported for a given field mapping value:

A nil string is represented by setting the chars field to NULL and specifying a length of 0. A nil string is distinguished from an empty string based on whether or not the chars field is NULL (in both cases the length is zero).
This type does not support specifying a .

Used when serializing two fields of a structure as a unit: a BYTE* field which points to an array of UTF8 bytes, and a ULONG field which contains the number of bytes in the array. This type may only be used within a .

The fields can be anywhere in the contained structure and in any order, since their offsets within the structure are specified separately as part of the . The offset of the count field is specified in the countOffset field, and the offset of the bytes field is specified in the offset field.
Embedded zeros are allowed in the array of utf8 bytes.
The type description can optionally be specified for this type in order to constrain the allowed values.
This type cannot be used with any values.
This type may only be used within a .

This type does not support specifying a .

The fields can be anywhere in the contained structure and in any order, since their offsets within the structure are specified separately as part of the . The offset of the count field is specified in the countOffset field, and the offset of the bytes field is specified in the offset field.

A nil array is represented by setting the array pointer field to NULL and specifying a length of 0. A nil array is distinguished from an empty array based on whether or not the array pointer field is NULL (in both cases the length is zero).
This type does not support specifying a .

This type requires a type description to be supplied which provides information about how to serialize the type, including a WS_READ_TYPE_CALLBACK and WS_WRITE_TYPE_CALLBACK which are used to read and write the type.
The callbacks are passed the and make the determination as to whether the mapping is supported.
The support for each value is dependent on the support determined by the callback. The rules are as follows:

item.description:
. This is used to initialize a field of a structure to a default value when deserializing. This is used for the case where the particular field does not have a mapping to the XML content, and the type is not one of the other s. The value will be initialized as follows:
If is specified, then the field will be set to NULL.
If is not specified, then the field will be set to the if allowed for the type and specified, otherwise it will be set to all zeros. The size of the field is specified as part of the . If a WS_VOID_DESCRIPTION is not specified, the field is interpreted as being size 0.

, WS_REPEATING_ANY_ELEMENT_FIELD_MAPPING, WS_ELEMENT_FIELD_MAPPING, WS_ATTRIBUTE_FIELD_MAPPING, WS_ANY_CONTENT_FIELD_MAPPING or WS_ANY_ATTRIBUTES_FIELD_MAPPING. This is used to discard the XML content when deserializing, or ignore the field when serializing. Since the values are not stored, a field of the structure is not required. The field offset should be zero and the field size should be zero (which is the default if a is not specified). The
option should not be used.
